content: Health care reform is a top priority for the 111th Congress due to concerns about the uninsured and rising healthcare costs. Improving access and controlling costs will require changes to financing and delivery. The National Priorities Partnership identified four major challenges in delivering high-quality care, including improving patient safety and eradicating disparities in care. The challenges in delivering high-quality care include eradicating disparities in care, reducing the burden of chronic disease, and eliminating unnecessary and ineffective care. Initiatives to address these challenges have been proposed in the health reform debate. The current healthcare system focuses on specialty care over primary care, leading to fragmented care for patients with multiple chronic conditions. Care coordination is essential to avoid waste and improve outcomes. Health workforce policy is crucial in addressing these challenges and improving the delivery of high-quality care. Health workforce policy is a key component in transforming the healthcare delivery system to focus more on primary care, disease prevention, and chronic illness management. The debate includes concerns about a future physician shortage and the need to balance increasing physician numbers with cost and quality considerations. Physician distribution varies based on preferences rather than patient needs. Health policy analysts recommend training more primary care physicians and developing integrated care systems to improve patient outcomes and quality of care. Clinical preventive services, such as immunizations and screening tests, are key in reducing healthcare costs and improving health. Health policy analysts suggest training more primary care physicians and creating integrated care systems to enhance patient outcomes and quality of care. Delivery reform advocates the medical home concept, aiming to improve care quality through patient-physician partnerships. Disease management programs, like those for diabetes, help patients self-manage through education, symptom monitoring, and treatment adherence. These programs aim to address rising chronic disease costs and care coordination issues. Health care delivery reform requires mechanisms to drive change in care systems, including performance measurement, comparative effectiveness research, health information technology adoption, and aligning payment incentives with high-quality care. Improvements in care quality depend on providers having financial incentives to change their delivery methods, which is hindered by the fee-for-service payment model. Public and private payers are increasingly tying provider payments to performance on quality measures to incentivize changes in the health care delivery system. The use of performance measures to track care quality is growing, but concerns about data development and use persist. Public reporting of quality information is crucial for helping patients make informed decisions about health care services. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA; P.L. 111-5) allocated $17 billion for health care reform, including $1.1 billion for comparative effectiveness research and $2 billion for Health Information Technology (HIT) grant programs. HIT is essential for electronic sharing of clinical data among health care stakeholders. Health Information Technology (HIT) is a vital component of health care reform, involving electronic health records, national health information network, and clinical decision support systems. HIT can improve efficiency by eliminating paper records, reducing duplicate tests, identifying drug interactions, and managing patients with multiple conditions. It also enables data for research and performance measurement.
